works_covered: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses
Further Remarks on the Neuro-Psychoses of Defence
Sexuality in the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: Defense consists in turning a strong idea into a weak one by robbing it of its affect
Pathogenic recollections are recognizable by patients describing them as unimportant while uttering them under resistance
Patients try to disown emerging pathogenic memories by claiming the analyst put them in their head
The analyst must remain unshakeable and recognize memories despite patients' disavowals and resistance
Hysterical patients of a visual type do not make such difficulties for the analyst as those with obsessions
Memory pictures become fragmentary and obscure as the patient describes them because describing converts them into words
When a memory picture remains obstinately before the patient's inward eye despite description, this indicates important material remains untold
Pathogenic psychical material is stratified in concentric layers around a pathogenic nucleus
Symptoms are overdetermined - a single symptom is determined in several ways by multiple pathogenic threads
Pathogenic material is organized according to thought-content through logical threads that take irregular, twisting paths to the nucleus
Pathogenic organization behaves not like a foreign body but like an infiltrate whose external strata pass imperceptibly into the normal ego
Treatment does not consist in extirpating pathogenic material but in causing resistance to melt and enabling circulation into cut-off regions
Only a single memory at a time can enter ego-consciousness through the defile of consciousness
It is hopeless to try to penetrate directly to the nucleus of the pathogenic organization even if the analyst could guess it
The analyst must work from the periphery inward radially while the patient handles the peripheral extension of the work
Gaps and imperfections in the patient's account reveal approaches to material in deeper layers
Neurosis does not relax the laws of logical connection and sufficient motivation in trains of thought
The analyst must reject the theoretical prejudice that hysterics have abnormal brains that throw overboard common psychological laws
Once concealed unconscious motives are discovered, nothing puzzling or contrary to rule remains in hysterical thought connections
Transference onto the physician occurs through a false connection when pathogenic wishes link to the analyst through compulsion to associate
Patients are deceived afresh every time transference repeats, not recognizing the false connection
Transference must be treated as a new symptom produced on the old model and made conscious to the patient
Transference resistances arise from fear of becoming sexually dependent on the physician
Patients must overcome the distressing affect of entertaining forbidden wishes whether in historical or present therapeutic instances
Transferences are compulsions and illusions that melt away with the conclusion of analysis
Failing to make the obstacle of transference clear would give patients a new hysterical symptom in exchange for the spontaneous one
Cathartic psychotherapy gains its justification not from removing pathology but from establishing conditions for healthier functioning
The goal of therapy is transforming hysterical misery into common unhappiness
The splitting of consciousness in defence hysteria results from an act of will on the part of the patient, not from innate weakness
Defence hysteria arises when the ego is faced with an incompatible idea that arouses such distressing affect that the subject decides to forget about it
In females incompatible ideas arise chiefly on the soil of sexual experience and sensation
In defence hysteria, the ego weakens the incompatible idea by transforming its sum of excitation into somatic innervation - this is conversion
The idea that has been weakened through conversion persists as a weak idea in consciousness or recurs during attacks
Hysterical conversion can be either total or partial
Ideational material in hysteria is transformed into chronic symptoms and acute attacks of hysteria
The conversion mechanism of defence hysteria can be arrived at by an effort of will
Defence hysteria and hypnoid hysteria are distinguishable forms with different mechanisms
In obsessions and phobias, separation of the incompatible idea from its affect occurs, but the affect remains in the psychical sphere
The liberated affect attaches itself to other suitable but not incompatible ideas, producing obsessional ideas or phobias
Transposition of affect is the mechanism of defence in obsessions and phobias
The ego gains less advantage from transposition of affect than from hysterical conversion because the affect remains unaltered and undiminished
Patients are astonished by their obsessional affects while the physician finds the affect justified but wrongly attached
Obsessional affects represent dislodged or transposed affects that can be retranslated into sexual terms
Liberated anxiety seizes upon common primary phobias of mankind or upon things unmistakably associated with the sexual
The separation of idea from affect and the false connection are processes that occur without consciousness
The processes of separation and false connection may be physical processes whose psychical consequences present themselves as if psychological changes had occurred
Patients aware of the sexual origin of their obsessions often keep them secret
A third method of defence leads to hallucinatory confusion where the ego rejects the incompatible idea together with its affect and behaves as if the idea had never approached it
In hallucinatory psychosis, the ego breaks away from the incompatible idea but this is inseparably attached to reality, so the ego also detaches itself from reality
The ego creates for itself a wishful psychosis in hallucinatory confusion as a substitute for the intolerable reality
Confusional psychosis is a defence mechanism available only to egos of particularly abnormal constitution
Defence neuropsychoses share the precondition that an incompatible idea has obtruded itself on the ego provoking a defensive reaction
The specific form of neurosis depends on whether the sum of excitation is converted into somatic, transposed onto other ideas, or leads to detachment from reality
The choice between different pathological outcomes depends on constitutional idiosyncrasy or psychical peculiarity
The defensive struggle culminates in a chronic abnormality only if the organic basis is suitable
Defence against an incompatible idea can fail to appear if the nervous system is intact and no serious hereditary taint exists
Whether a neurotic illness occurs depends upon a quantitative factor - the total load on the nervous system compared with its capacity for resistance
positions.source: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: Heredity acts like a multiplier that increases the dimensions of neurosis but does not determine its form
positions.source: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: What form the neurosis assumes is solely determined by the specific aetiological factor arising from sexual life
positions.source: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: Nervous disorders can develop in people who are perfectly healthy and whose family is above reproach, as seen in neurasthenia
positions.source: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: Hereditary predisposition is merely a precondition of neurosis, not its specific cause - it cannot explain episodic onset or cessation through treatment
positions.source: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: The specific aetiology of hysteria is a passive sexual experience before puberty
positions.source: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: Hysterical symptoms are always traced back to an event in the subject's sexual life appropriate for producing distressing emotion
positions.source: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: The specific cause of hysteria is a precocious experience of sexual relations with actual genital excitement from sexual abuse by another person before age eight to ten
positions.source: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: Sexual relations between children often continue for years, with the boy repeating practices to which he was subjected by servants or governesses
positions.source: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: Passive sexual experience occurring after age eight to ten is no longer able to serve as the foundation of neurosis
positions.source: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: Patients never repeat traumatic sexual stories spontaneously - memories must be extracted piece by piece under energetic pressure and against enormous resistance
positions.source: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: While traumatic sexual memories are being awakened, patients become prey to emotion that would be hard to counterfeit
positions.source: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: The precocious sexual event leaves an indelible imprint represented by a host of symptoms and special features that could be accounted for in no other way
positions.source: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: Precocious sexual excitation produces little or no effect at the time but its psychical trace is preserved and awakened at puberty
positions.source: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: Thanks to changes at puberty, the memory of childhood sexual trauma displays a power completely lacking from the event itself - operating as though it were a contemporary event
positions.source: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: The awakening of a sexual memory after puberty when the event happened long before forms the only psychological instance of a memory's effect surpassing that of the actual event
positions.source: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: This posthumous action of sexual trauma is an abnormal constellation that touches a weak side of the psychical mechanism and produces pathological effect
positions.source: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: The inverse relation between the psychical effect of memory and of the event contains the reason for the memory remaining unconscious
positions.source: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: Obsessional neurosis differs from hysteria in that sexual memories relate to actions performed with pleasure rather than passive experiences
positions.source: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: In obsessional neurosis, active sexual experiences in early childhood preceded by passive sexual experiences form the specific aetiology
positions.source: Heredity and the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: The most immediate and practically significant causes of every case of neurotic illness are found in factors arising from sexual life
positions.source: Sexuality in the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: A physician investigating neuroses cannot avoid asking patients about their sexual life and insisting upon receiving a true account
positions.source: Sexuality in the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: Objections against inquiring into sexual life express prudery unworthy of a physician that inadequately conceals its weakness behind bad arguments
positions.source: Sexuality in the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: No one ever becomes neurotic through work or excitement alone - intellectual work is rather a protection against neurasthenia
positions.source: Sexuality in the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: The most unremitting intellectual workers remain exempt from neurasthenia
positions.source: Sexuality in the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: Sexual aetiology makes it possible to understand all details of neurasthenic clinical history including mysterious improvements and incomprehensible deteriorations
positions.source: Sexuality in the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: Removal from home in hydropathic treatment entails interruption of marital intercourse, making temporary elimination of pathogenic cause possible
positions.source: Sexuality in the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: With neurasthenia, therapeutic problems must be attacked within the framework of the patient's life, not in hydropathic institutions
positions.source: Sexuality in the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: Masturbation is far commoner among grown-up girls and mature men than generally supposed and produces neurasthenic symptoms
positions.source: Sexuality in the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: Coitus interruptus practiced regularly produces neurotic symptoms
positions.source: Sexuality in the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: Natural intercourse during pregnancy provides a curative effect on neurosis
positions.source: Sexuality in the Aetiology of the Neuroses

positions.position: Charcot was not a reflective thinker but an artist-scientist who was a 'visuel' - a man who sees
Charcot's method was to look repeatedly at things he did not understand until suddenly understanding dawned - the apparent chaos gave way to order
Nosography - the intellectual work of seeing new nosological pictures emerge from apparent chaos - was Charcot's particular gift
The greatest satisfaction in science is to see something new - to recognize it as new
